element_texts.text:
J. & S. SMITH
Newsagents - wholesale and Retail Tobacconists and Stationers
28, Swadford Street,  Skipton
Telephone: 2829
Oct. 13th 64
Dear Jack/ Many, many thanks for your book "Disinherited." I thoroughly enjoyed it & had
you constantly in mind whilst reading it.  Would have replied sooner but have been short of
staff & seemed to have too much to do this last few weeks.  I hope the remainder of your holiday
was not spoiled by rain. Your book will always be a reminder of a few delightful days holiday in
Ireland & good porter, Guinness & Whiskey.   Hoping you & your good lady are in the best of health.

 Yours   J. Smith

P.S. A North Country Calendar for 1965
should be with you within a couple of weeks  JS...

4819 W. 139th ST.
Hawthorne, Calif. 90250
July 2, 1970
Dear Mr. Conroy,

 I am planning to write my thesis for the Masters Degree in American Literature on fiction published

During the Depression.  Perhaps I can impose on your kindness and ask you where I could find magazines
such as Anvil and Rebel Post which you edited.  I grew up during the Depression, and I seem never to have
escaped it physically or economically. Now I have returned to college. I want to view that period through
the eyes of the poets and writers who found a voice in the little magazines.

Your book The Disinherited is in my belief a great book.
Sincerely yours,
Kathleen R. Smith

4819 W. 139th ST.
Hawthorne, Calif. 90250
July 23, 1970
Dear Mr. Conroy,

Please forgive my handwriting. My typewriter has fallen apart, and I am looking for a good machine

at little or no cost. This is not a pollyannaish attitude of mind. Lately I have experienced a good many
unusual happenings. To name a few: I got a summer job at the College as a research assistant in the Sociology Department. 
Since I am an English major and older I might be considered the least likely choice to study the communes and the new
life style. I have, however, met young people who are deeply involved in the communes of a very high level. You, I think
would understand them very well. Your letter and your material reinforce my personal belief that the quality of a human being
can be found in what he does and what he writes.  A far better Master's thesis might be built around you as a writer and why your
work escaped the sterile, lifelessness of much so-called proletarian literature.  I have xeroxed your materials and am returning the
originals to you.

Dominguez Hills is a new college whose library facilities are as yet limited. I shall check UCLA library for the periodicals you suggest.
Failing that, I shall write to the Library of Congress.

Thank you for saying that I may write to you as my thesis develops. I shall do so. I think we are entering into a period where the 1930's will be

studied and re-evaluated. Until now, it was too terrible and too close. I find two polarities of mind in the writing of that period - One I call the
anti-life kind of mind. The other, represented by you, is surprisingly close to what the best of minds of the younger generation are saying. The phrase
'the new Life style' emphasizes life at its fullest and most compassionate. As I said, you would understand it very well.

Sincerely,
Kathleen R. Smith

4819 W. 39th St.
Hawthorne, California 90250
Nov. 15, 1970
213-679-6226
Dear Mr. Conroy,

Last summer you were good enough to send me some material. You may be interested to know that your book The Disinherited

is being used in classes at California State College, Dominguez Hills. Next quarter your book will be used in a class in American
Studies.   At present I am doing a study on Josephine Herbst, who died last year. Can you give me any of your personal and literary
insights on her and on her work? In some of her  novels, her writing is very good. In my judgment they will never be read again to
any marked degree. Your book has life. Hers do not.  I shall appreciate any help you can give me. If you do not have time to write,
we could set up a telephone time where i could call you. Or if you could tape any thoughts I would be glad to defray the expense.

Sincerely,
Kathleen R. Smith

Jan 4, 1971
Dear Mr. Conroy,

My reply to your letter never got in the mail. It was lost in a mass of final exam material. I apologize

for the delay in answering your good letter -

Kathleen R. Smith

4819 W. 139th Street
Hawthorne, Calif. 90250
December 8, 1970
Dear Mr. Conroy,

You are a rare, extraordinary person. One who answers letters, and one who writes so vividly. 

Thank you for your good suggestions. I did an interesting experiment with Josephine Herbst prose.
I taped two hours of The Rope of Gold and  played it back. I hoped to learn why her character never
got off the page. I believe one reason is that her prose style was entirely unsuited to her story line. In
that book, indeed in all her books, her people are sterile and defeated. somehow the reader does not 
believe they will shape a better social order. Jonathan couldn't write anymore. Victoria couldn't bear a
living child. Neither of then could love. Out of death they try to create a decent world. No Way! In
your novel The Disinherited the characters are so alive they jump our of the pages. Perhaps Miss
Herbst's portrait of you as Barney Evans

was inspired by envy of this quality in your novel. Failure is bitter, and a writer knows the feel of failure.
I find none of the Herbst books in paperback. In fact most libraries do not ^ in red any of her books/red
have them at all. Some libraries have hidden them in depositories. I seen to be the only one in the area requesting
their resurrection.  I will not wish you a merry Christmas, because, frankly, I hate the season. This year I plan to drop out
from the songs, the tree, the cheer. Instead, I shall work at the Help Line Telephone Clinic where the lonely, the defeated of this
area call in. Sometimes they ask who cares if they kill themselves. I tell them I do.  What I shall wish you is a year in which you
will write a novel, your memoirs. Such writing as yours is never "disinherited" for long.

 Sincerely,
Kathleen R. Smith

Kathleen R. Smith
4819 W. 139th Street
Hawthorne, Calif. 90250
August 15, 1971
Dear Mr. Conroy,

I am delighted to get your letter. I am in the throw of writing the Herbst paper, and only last week I re-read

your letter. Again I must thank you for your help. Your suggestion to contact Malcolm Cowley was invaluable.
In my thesis I am treating your novel, "The Disinherited". In contrast to J. Herbst "Rope of  Gold" it succeeds where
hers failed.  Next year I shall be teaching English at a near-by high school. High schools are beginning to introduce
seminars for honor students. In the course of time I hope to introduce a course in proletarian fiction, and shall, of course,
use your novel.  I shall collect some of my

2.  good source material for what I am persuading the College library to accumulate - too-long neglected writers
of that era. I am sending the information on "the American Book Collection" to the college librarian, to the chairman
of the English Department, and to a professor in the History Department whose interest is Americana. Of course I shall
personally subscribe.  In a letter of November 25, 1970 you mentioned a Mrs. Mary Butler and a Dorothy Farrell whom 
J. Herbst knew in Chicago. Do you know the addresses of either. I am trying to find someone who knows about the breakup
of the J.Herbst-John Hermann marriage. I believe Herrmann, who died in 1959, appeared in her fiction. She did not, regrettably,
learn much from his prose style.

With all good wishes,
Kathleen R. Smith

4819 W. 139th Street
Hawthorne, Calif. 90250
10/13/71
Dear Mr. Conroy,

I am abject at not answering your wonderful letter of August 22. A death in the family came between me

and life for a while.  I xeroxed copies of your enclosures. The review of "Zelda" hits the core of the problem.
How many writers have been destroyed by marrying the wrong mates? Scott, I think, was one whose evil demon
led him to select the most destructive wife around around. I plan to use this review in my high school class when
I knock "The Great Gatsby" into their heads. Also, I hope to influence the school librarian into buying "The Disinherited"
for use in English and social studies classes.  The Herbst thing goes well. There was another destructive marriage.

2.
I have written to the address you gave me, and hope to get a few nuggets of information.

How goes your autobiography? This is of primary interest to me. The sheet you enclosed on the salesman's

pitch is a gem. Of course, I am using it in my classes also!

Best wishes,
Kathleen R. Smith

How's everything in the Atkins? 9th West? I had a bad fall, emergency surgery, and two weeks -
in the hospital recently. I'm gradually mending, thank God

 Ora

red printing
WISHING YOU Holiday joy, Holiday cheer,
And holiday happiness All throughout the year. /red

It's been a long time since our "Folly" days on Wells St. I've spent

most of '81 recovering from a serious accident. arrow to top of page
The accident was a fall from a ladder and being impaled on a metal post, 
shattering my urethra. It was touch and go for several months.   Barbara's fine;
hope Gladys and you are too. Our best for '82   Ora & Barb

in pencil O.R. Snapp Dec 1982

Cheers! How are both of you. I still hear from two of the gals

I worked with at E.B. Our health is reasonably good; I'm now 78, Barbara 75.
We had to cancel a bus trip into Eastern Canada this summer because she
was temporarily ill.  Best for '83      Orv

CONROY--3--

Schneider was very pleased to have us feature his name on the back page. I saw him Friday night (Nov. 30th) at the NEW MASSES ball and he greeted me as if

I were his favorite brother!    No. 9, on the whole, is swell! I was afraid that we wouldn't have any name like Le Sueur to help us swing the magazine. Moss, Clemente,
Leopold and Tom Butler are OK.  But let me have those left-over MSS promptly. You will, of course, send them by first-class mail.    Will Wharton asked me to dope out some
advertising rates but I must collect some data first. Hereafter, however, we must not allow a little mag with 300 circulation to have an exchange add with ANVIL on a
fifty-fifty basis. The add policy in No. 9 was OK.    with best wishes and a fighting promise to make ANVIL a success or go to the poorhouse i the attempt!

 signed  Walter Snow   Walter Snow

P.S. - Didn't you get my last letter?
P.P.S. - Dennen gets a swell review from Adamic in the current Nation.  Poor Newhouse is getting mainly shabby treatment - a bastardly two-paragraph review in today's Herald-Trib
under "Popular Novels."   Melvin levy's new play "Gold Eagle Guy" appears to be slated to clean up a "Tobacco Road" fortune. "Turnips" Caldwell can buy a Long Island mansion.
Only nineteen other plays in the past twenty years have likewise run a solid year on Broadway says today's Herald-Trib. Caldwell really is a skinflint in not giving the Anvil
$1,000.00!!  I mean it, too. I'll wager he has salted away his first $100,000.00

an interview with author of Summer Time Ends
Bobbs Merrill Co.
468 4th Ave.
NYC

Bertha Fenberg, 4510,  5234 Dorchester Ave.  Chicago
Benj. Gershman, 2111 S. Harding Ave., Chi.

April 21, 1969
Dear Jack -

Still exhausted as I had to review a play SAT NITE & was writing

a piece on LARRY HILL up until DAWN Today. Hill piece may appear Tomorrow.

Will write later -   Meanwhile - some clippings
Best   Walt

in red ink
Feb 24, 1971
Dear Jack -

In case you are flooded with too many mags & didn't get a chance to peak in WORMWOOD No. 40, here's a piece on Briggs -

One of the old REBEL POETS is a bookseller who used to handle the early ANVILS before NEW+ crossed out NEW MASSES distribution took
over with that psychic? sweep -   The ^late summer WORMWOOD, possibly No 41 or 42 should have my long (280 line) dramatic
monologue, ROBERT BROWNING AT TWILIGHT.   I've been struggling to do another one - BEN JONSON RECALLS  an obscene
playwright (BOUND IN SHALLOWS) & rewriting & rearranging endlessly.   This is getting to be 400 lines - a picture of the Elizabethan
Guab Street -     Best      Walter Snow

April 25, 1971
Dear Jack -

Thanks for Reviews which will to to Mickey Stern after I make ZEROXES.

and thanks for Dahlberg. Note one of his correspondents is ISABELLA GARDNER, who gave
MILLIONS to BOSTON ART MUSEUM - & supported a string of GIGELO AUTHORS.

Just scribbling so as not to awaken Flora.  Sorry you were hospitalized - DIABETES is rough but

controllable. ME - also have blood pressure problem - too low - have been on 20 drops
of BELLADONA TINCTURE. 4 times daily. Flora on tranquilizer. Both trying to hold together
for next 2 weeks & 2 days before we take off on our last Big Italian Trip - one canceled last Sept
due to Flora's 11th hour gall bladder operation.   We're going despite fact she used up all VACATION &
SICK TIME & must take FOUR WEEKS without pay.   More on my return

Best  Walt

VENEZIA
Plaza S. Marco  Place S. Marco
S. Marco Square  Markusplatz
postmark VENEZIA
stamp UNA VITA NORMALE PER IL DIABETICO
FRI May 13
Dear Jack & Gladys

All poets from Byron to Shelley to Browning to Ezra Pannil understated

VENICE. Ar. Th?.. off SUW? on 2 week cruise on YUGO MS ISTRIA
Best  Walter & Flora SNOW
Mr & Mrs Jack Conroy
701 FISK AVE
MOBERLY MISSOURI 65270 USA
in pencil 1971?

July 3, 1971
Dear Jack -

 This was probably our last trip - even if we keep our jobs for another year.

That's unlikely. We have a GOP governor, MESKILL (first in 16 years)
who's as mad as Reagan & is chopping welfare to hell. heads rolling all around Flora & I'm
getting to [sic] old to keep mad Chronicle pace.  Even on our trip we had to limit sight-seeing
to a half day most of the time & use extra time for recuperating.  I had 2 mild attacks & then 
sprained my ankle twice ! ? Flora also sprained hers.   But many half days were glorious. If
I only knew a publisher who'd take a travel book. But only a couple of poetry editors now want anything of mine

Best to you & yours    Walt Snow

From the desk of WALTER SNOW
Sept 8, 1971
Dear Jack -

I'm taking THREE MONTHS to WRITE ABOUT MY FIVE-WEEK TRIP

(but it was my last)   Kissed off ten Greek stops in 3 articles - each with
digs about dictator=COLONELS & were a jab at MUSSOLINI
Will wind up series with 4 on ROME.   Hope you & Gladys are well.

 Best  Walt

Oct 7, 1971
Dear Jack

Here endeth the long  series with a plug for my BROWNING poem in a story about Florence.

Writing article inspired a few revisions of published poem.  Best to you & Gladys. From here
on I'll be lucky to appear in print two or three times a year.    As ever    Walt

Dec 23 - 72
Dear Gladys & Jack -

Just forward two enclosed.  Keep JACK working on our ERA'S BEST AUTO BIOGRAPHY.

First Chapter equals best of the great DISINHERITED.   MY GLORY may not ARRIVE 
here until MID or LATE JAN.    All the Best     Walter

Friday, April 6, 1973
Dear Jack -

Here are the requested 25 LEAFLETS - Eight on Top MARKED  B in upper rt hand corner good for

Paperback.   Other 17 have paperback order crossed out.  Letter to you on FOOLKILLER went out this AM.
YUKON follows EARLHAM as 2nd Library ordering both.  Will express your best to Canuth?

Gratefully      Walter Snow

POSTCARD
OCEANSIDE, OREGON
Excellent beaches, good surf and rock fishing. Scenic beauty unsurpassed.
stamps three 2 c
postmark POSTAL SERVICE . OR  25 MAR 1973
TIERRA DEL MAR OREGON

WCD - May 23, 1973

Dear Jack - We're 40 ft from PACIFIC OCEAN - 100 MILES SW of Portland
for a few days We leave FRIDAY for Portland & will RetuRN oN EMPIRE BUILDER -
Going THRU GLACIER NATIONAL PARK - EN Route we CAME SOUTHERN
ROAD THRU BADLANDS, ALONG YELLOWSTONE RIVER   & crossed Rockies just
before Butte, MONTANA   HOME MAX 29 -  Best WALTER SNOW
HON. JACK CONROY
The SAGE OF Moberly,
MOBERLY, MISSOURI  65270

letterhead
Mrs. Joseph A. Snyder
2100 Tomahawk Road
Shawnee Mission
Kansas 66208
April 15 '71
362-4123
Dear Mr. Conroy -

Last week I was in Lawrence and at a luncheon met Ned Kehde who said that you had known

H.L. Mencken Many years ago. I understand you have letters of his and possibly other things.
I have an extensive collection of Mencken, which will some day be in the Spencer Library at K.U.
I would be interested in hearing from you. If you are ever in Kansas City would you call?
By any chance do you subscribe

to the Enoch Pratt Library of Baltimore's "Menckeniana"? I know Betty Adler quite well - maybe you
would have some interesting stories for her to publish about Mencken -     Cordially -

Elizabeth Snyder

letterhead
Mrs. Joseph A. Snyder
2100 Tomahawk Road
Shawnee Mission, Kansas 66208
July 5, 1971
Dear Mr. Conroy -

It has been a long time since your letter of April 17 - forgive my delay. Joe & I went to

England for 5 weeks so many other things "went by the boards"   My Mencken Collection
will go to K.U. - some of it I hope by this Fall. I feel that the letters and newspaper articles -
Smart Sets - and Mercurys would be better Cared

for than in our house.  Have you had contact with Kansas and the Spencer Library?
would you consider selling your letters if they would be in the collections there? -
Of course, better still, your own contribution - tax deduction et al - would still keep
your identity -   Think it over - please call us should you be in Kansas City
Most sincerely -    Elizabeth Snyder

P.S. - continued - Our library gets it. I've got half a notion to buy a copy every year for myself. I think it's
a very good reference book.

Sunday morning
Feb. 13, 1983
John Sobieski
Rt. 6 Box 580
Chippewa Falls, Wis.  54729

Dear Jack,
 I hope you don't mind reading my handwriting, but Joanne is still asleep and I don't want to wake her

with the typewriter. It's only 7 a.m.

I had an interesting day, yesterday, but also have a hang-over today. I went to the village of Cadot, about

9 miles east of here, to get a gasket for our dishwasher door. The man who runs the IGA grocery store
also is the Maytag dealer.

So, I got the gasket and on the way home, I stopped at the Landfill Lounge tavern (so named because it

is on the corner where the road goes to our town dump. It's a small country bar where one can meet his
neighbors and have a good conversation. Sherman, the owner, had put up a big sign on the wall:
"To celebrate our 5th anniversary of screwing the public - Beer 25¢ - Bar Booze 50¢ - Month of February."
Well, as long as a glass of beer was only a quarter I couldn't help but stay there a while. A man who I haven't
seen for a long time came in and we had a long talk. He is a batchelor [sic] and will be 64 soon and is thinking of
retiring - he's marketing manager

2
for National Presto Industries in Eau Claire. You've probably heard of Presto pressure cookers, and electric fry pans & etc.
(I used to work there as assistant advertising manager until I got banged up in a bad car accident in 1970) - anyway, Bob's 
worried that if he retires he doesn't know what he'll do with himself. Since I'm only 38 years old and haven't worked for a
long time I couldn't offer much advice. Bob said that if he retires this spring he might go to Alaska and do some fishing
and back-packing. He always has been a sportsman. This winter he gave up down-hill skiing. In the last three years he fell
on the hills and broke his leg twice and his arm once.  

  After I had enough beer there, I sent to another country bar near here, Lawler's, and drank more beer and got into an 

argument with a county supervisor who is a friend of mine (I hope he's underlined: still  a friend after yesterday). He is 
one of them on the county board who has been rather stingy about funding our public library.

  I also got some good tips on how to prune fruit tree from another friend who owns an apple orchard near here. Three miles

from here is the second-largest apple producing area in Wisconsin. Door County, over to the East, near Green Bay, is the first.
We have a plum tree, a sour cherry tree and a couple of flowering crabs in our back yard.

3
They all need a little pruning. Now that we got a lot of snow the rabbits are getting hungry and they have been chewing up my spirea bushes which
decorate one corner of the house. I've got a notion to sit up some night with my .410 shotgun and wait for them. Night-time is when they come out.

There are a lot of rabbits around here. I had a terrible time with them in our vegetable garden last summer. I always give son Tony a little garden space

of his own and the rabbits ate all the beans and lettuce. I think this spring I'm going to invest in some kind of fence. another thing that works well is dried
cow's blood. It's sold as a fertilizer and can be purchased at any feed & fertilizer store.

I ordered all my garden seeds for this year, mostly from Burpee's in Iowa and from Park's in Carolina. I've always had good luck with their seeds. There is

another company, Mellinger's, which is a wholesale house that sells mostly to commercial growers, and I ordered a few things from them, too. Their seed
catalog is somewhat unusual because there aren't the typical pictures of their products. And where else can one buy carrot seeds and rutabaga seeds
by the hundred-weight?

4
Dick ordered your THE DISINHERITED for our library, here. But he said this spring they have to buy a lot of children's books, mostly replacements of those that are getting worn and shabby.
Every spring the Public Library has their "Great 10¢ Book Sale" during which they sell all their discards for a dime. Last year I bought an old copy of Woodrow Wilson's Congressional Government. That was the first I ever read that book and I think it's a neglected document. I discussed that book with out congressman Dave Obey at a picnic last summer. He knows the book well - he's got an M.A. in political science - and he wonders how many of his collegues [sic] in Washington have even heard of the book. Dave also doubts that Reagan has ever read the Constitution of the U.S.
I took your advice and read everything I could find about Sen. Gary Hart and am now gathering support for him in northern Wisconsin. I am to be a delegate for Chippewa County at our spring Democrat district convention in April and then will be able to really get the ball rolling.
We have certainly been blessed with a mild winter this year. Here it is Feb 13, and at 7a.m. the temperature was already 34° above.

5

I wrote three short stories this winter, one of them just last Sunday. it was the result of a hilarious dream I had - 

I woke up laughing - and I couldn't resist writing it down. When I wrote it everything just fell into place. It's my
very first humorous story. The title is "Danny After the Changes," and it's about a family and their ill-mannered half-wit 
son who has all kinds of fake degrees and who goes around telling strangers that some one is about to rape his sister, Sophia.

As soon as I have it neatly typed up I'll send it to some magazine. Don't know where yet. If I get to town this week I'll xerox

off a copy and send it to you.      Write me a note some day.

Sincerely,   John

THE SOCIETY OF MIDLAND AUTHORS
June 27, 1971
Minocqua, Wis.
stamped
LOUIS E. LAFLIN, 'JR.
205 MAYFLOWER ROAD
LAKE FOREST, ILLINOIS
BOX 631  60045
MR JACK CONROY
VICE-PRESIDENT FOR MISSOURI
701 FISK STREET
MOBERLY, MISSOURI 65270

Dear Jack Conroy:
 It is my sincere hope that the Society of Midland authors may become truly representative of its name.

As Vice-President for Missouri, are you willing, from time to time, to submit recommendations for membership
of qualified writers from your state?

For the Annual Meeting, usually in May, will you attend and read a brief (1 page) report on the creative writing

in your state published during the past year? Being unable to attend, will you send a proxy representative, or appoint
someone in Chicago to read your report, or permit us to choose a reader for it?

If our Society could have, and file, such annual reports, I feel it would more truly be fulfilling its professed functions
  Cordially yours
  Ellsworth Laflin
 (President)

in left margin:  WANTED: Vice-Presidents for both Dakotas

There are 2 Missouri members (including you) Local State Chapters may be established
with 5 members, when properly approved according to the new By-laws
1. CONROY, Jack - Vice President
2. CONSTANT, Mrs. Alberta Wilson
1841 Vassar Ave.
Independence, MO. 64052

THE SOCIETY OF MIDLAND AUTHORS
July 11, 1971
stamped
LOUIS E. LAFLIN, 'JR.
205 MAYFLOWER ROAD
LAKE FOREST, ILLINOIS
BOX 631  60045
MR JACK CONROY
VICE-PRESIDENT FOR MISSOURI
701 Fisk in redSt, Lane, Blvd?
Moberly, Missouri 65270

 Dear Mr. Conroy:

I hope for a reply to my letter of June 27th soon, or we are virtually a new Society and need ^confirmation there is one other
Missouri member: Mrs. Alberta Wilson Constant of 1891 Vassar Ave., Independence, MO. 64052.  I hope you will send in the 
names, addresses, books, and publishers of more Missouri authors, and make a brief report (1 page) on ^the years writing in
Missouri for the annual meeting in Chicago in May 1972.

If you cannot give it yourself you can send a proxy, or let us find someone to read it. It will then be filed.
Now that we are to be incorporated not for profit, you can take a deduction

as an officer, on your travelling ^and other expenses for Society business. (contribution, on income tax return).

Four members may form a state chapter, with the approval of the Chicago board of directors. I hope each of our 

[[tu?lr?] states will have a representative membership and that we will truly become a society of Midland Authors,
with chapters in every state.       Cordially yours,

 Ellsworth Laflin

We need to hear from our Vice-Presidents, in order to plan new letter-paper. New State members  could get into a new 
membership list. I should like to see the society re-born before the new season begins next fall.

Huron Mountain Club
Big Bay, Marquette County, Michigan (Home tomorrow)
THE SOCIETY OF MIDLAND AUTHORS
August 1st, 1971
stamped
LOUIS E. LAFLIN, 'JR.
205 MAYFLOWER ROAD
LAKE FOREST, ILLINOIS
BOX 631  60045
Jack Conroy, ESQ.
Vice-President For Missouri
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri 65270

set off at the top  We are waiting for a general overhauling, before printing new letter-paper. Besides, it seems more thrifty to use up the old.
Dear Jack Conroy:
 Thank you for your kind, prompt and admirable letter of July 14th. I agree with you that it is much better for your proposed candidates for

membership to be invited from headquarters.

You will be sent a list of our present members, and the text of our new constitution (incorporated not for profit) shortly. You will note that recent 

presidents have invited personal friends not always qualified as creative writers. The new Constitution seeks to emphasize the creative writer, in history, 
travel, fiction, poetry, drama and the like, with published books, by recognized publishers.

All present members will retain their

present status, but in the future, it is proposed to admit editors, publishers, librarians and writers of
How-to-do-it books, or very technical books, as underlined Associate Members. /underline

It is my hope to build up the underline regular /underline members, especially the State membership, first.
One of your nominees, Dr. French, has written "critical studies" and another, Mr. Thorpe Mann, is a literary editor

(and author). - Should these two, and all the others be invited as regular members? In other words, do these ^two
both qualify as authors of published books of "creative writing."

I am sorry to trouble you with this further question, but you will see why this knowledge is desirable.
underline CONFIDENTIAL /underline 

For the past 20 (maybe more) years, all members have been passed on underline solely by /underline Miss
Fanny Butcher, the dean of Chicago literary critics, who has never written a book herself! Her autobiography comes
out this fall. She has considered books of poems, published-plays and paper-backs to be underline not books at all! /underline
The board feels that this policy must be changed.

Cordially yours,  Ellsworth Laflin.

letterhead
Barbara Probst Solomon
5737 South Dorchester Avenue  Chicago, Illinois
(Mrs Harold Solomon)  ? 13-0130
Dear Jack -

Can't find you in the phone book - we are living in Chicago

this year - Hal visiting prof at the law school -
do give us a ring     Sincerely,
Barbara Solomon

in pencil Solomon, Barbara
Barbara Probst Solomon 271 Central Park West New York 24, N.Y.
Feb 1, 1960
Dear Mr Conroy,

I was delighted to hear from you - and most appreciative of ^ the so many things you've

done - and I do hope you've done - and I do hope you'll be coming this way soon.
I was glad to sign the books - though I have such a wretched handwriting - I didn't know
how good it came out -  At moment, I am hard at work -    Thanks again,

Barbara Solomon

P.S. did you see review of book in [issue] Partisan Review?

in pencil  Solomon, Barbara [no date]
Barbara Probst Solomon 271 Central Park West New York 24, N.Y.
Dec
Dear Mr Conroy -

Mike forwarded me your very nice letter, and I want you to know I am

most appreciative of your enthusiastic review - and am delighted with any
interest on the part of your friend - with the new book club -

At the moment

I am about to publish another novel - only this time for Random House -

If you ever get to New York, my husband and I would like very much to

meet you -    Sincerely,

March 17, 1969
Dear Jack:

     A good question that; how am I faring at SF State?  Pretty badly, as a matter of grim fact.  Your old colleague Hiawatha considers me "the most dangerous and influential member of the faculty," and has sworn to fire me; for my part, I am convinced he is as mad as the proverbial March hare, and a punitive right-wing witch hunter to boot.  Und so.  There is not, I assume, much question over who will win, but I'll go down fighting.  We have been fighting here, for the past 3 months, and it has been the good fight, for, I believe firmly, the side of life as opposed to death.  It was a pretty good strike.  I learned a lot:  how to be a picket captain; that day after day in the rain would not melt me; that cops are not my friends; that there can be such a thing (even among teachers) as solidarity; that a minority can hang tough; that it is possible to work, and to work well with these black kids, despite their tremendous sense of outrage--that if one can put something on the line, one can gain a measure of trust, but only by commiting [sic] oneself.  And, alas, I've learned that nothing is simple.  We creaked back in with a lousy settlement, minus 2 months' salary, and with matters still unresolved.  It is like teaching in a concentration camp, now, and I'm unsettled as hell.  I feel as schizoid as we all do here.  Part of us wants to partake of the simpler attitudes of the picket line, while part wants to take over, despite the odds, the governance of the institution.  I don't give myself long here, but I'm going to try to hang on another year --partly because the black kids have asked me to.
   Your lecture tour sounds great.  Sure, the company is pretty fast, but you've got the credentials.  I'm using underlined:  The Disinherited this year in a weird and wild class called "Literature and Revolution" (filled with black, Third World, and striking students); that wonderful passage dealing with the men working on the road building is beautifully vital.

added to typescript in handwriting

   I'll be in touch.  And I'll give  your love to Hiawatha if he comes back from praying (sp.?) with Nixon.
   If you discover any nice documents at the U. of Conn. bash, grab a copy for me.

All the best,  Eric
P.S.  It's St. Pat's day.  They used to call me Sullivan when I was a tad in Boston. Anyone can pass, I guess.  Cheers.

in pencil 1961
SAN FRANCISCO STATE COLLEGE
1600 Holloway Avenue  San Francisco, California 94132
School of Humanities

letterhead
JEANNETTE ST. L. SOMERS
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
February 7th, 1943.
My dear Mr. Conroy:

Every time I see a review signed "Jack Conroy" I am tempted to write. First, because I enjoy your articles so

very much, and second, because two years ago at the Oakenwald School, I taught a most interesting, sensitive 
little boy of the same name. Ordinarily, one remembers only the imps, sentimentalists to the contrary, and there
were plenty of them at the Oakenwald, but sometimes one finds a kindred spirit to look back upon. I have often
wondered whether the Jack Conroy I taught for the short space of three months, was your son. I remember him 
because he was so obviously of superior background and because he was the type every teacher looks for and so
seldom finds - the one who gives you an understanding  look when

letterhead
JEANNETTE ST. L. SOMERS
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
something funny or out of the ordinary comes up, a kind of "we-get-the-point" look. I don't remember
a thing about his scholarship, simply that he was a real personality.  I like your reviews. They show deep
culture, but you don't write like a college professor, a brand of writing that I hate. You write as though
you've always lived with and loved books, but also as if you had lived a life of your own, and felt
them as something more than literature.  I enjoyed your review on "The Dickens Digest" especially
because I agree with you whole-heartedly on digests and boiled down versions. I read for the style
and savor of an author, not for any "message" or uplift, just a kind of pagan enjoyment. Dickens
without the minor characters wouldn't have any interest for me. It's a good many years since I've
gone in for any Dickensian reading and I don't remember a thing about

letterhead
JEANNETTE ST. L. SOMERS
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
the "social satire" that you so slyly grin over, but I do remember Mr. Mantallini and Miss
Henry Henrietta Petowker and the old man in "David Copperfield" who scared David with
his "O my lights and livers! Goo roo, Goo roo! Those things spell Dickens for me.
I got a kick out of your references to Gilbert and Sullivan and to "Alice." I was
brung up on G.& S. and have loved Alice for forty two years, ever since the time I saved
soap wrappers and sent away for my copy to Armour's or Swift's, I don't remember which.
My battered red "Alice" shares the shelves with much more sophisticated volumes, but it
and "Huckleberry Finn" remain my first loves.   May an aging school ma'rm tell you that
she is one of your fans, and still keep out of the adolescent class? I figger [sic] that I'm old enough 
now to tell people when I like things.    Sincerely, (Mrs.) Jeannette St. Lawrence Somers

letterhead
JEANNETTE ST. L. SOMERS
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
April 11th, 1943.
Dear Mr. Conroy,

I don't know whether I can convey to you how intensely interested I found your letter, even though I have

waited so long to tell you. That you got your education the hard way explains some of the quality of your writing, 
but very fortunately you have escaped the thing that often goes with self made people in any line, but especially
in education: you haven't lost your individuality.   I suppose it's high treason to my profession to say it, but you
didn't miss anything by not going to high school. I put in four years of torture, every day of which I hated, but
I knew that I had to stick it out, because the family was determined to make a teacher out of me. Looking back,
I can see that all I got out of it was a good

grounding in French and German grammar and nothing else, because I still don't understand
mathematics and never will. Everything else I could have absorbed by reading, for I had long
before formed that habit.  I was much interested in "Horatuio" [sic] as the start of your career. No
ordinary kid would have picked it - in fact, they don't like poetry at all. I, too read all of Alger
and Henty and Harry Castleman, for girls' books were never my meat. The wilder they came,
the better I liked them, which was strange, because I was very quiet and shy, and not at all a
tomboy.  The first long story I ever read was "East Lynne" at the age of 8. I cried over Lady Isabelle
and hated Sir Francis Levinson, and years later, when I had my own home I bought a copy and gave
it a permanent place in my book-case. My husband was worried afraid people would think I was a 
low-brow, much as my mother felt when at 10 years old, I crashed a Polish wedding and was dancing

2  letterhead
JEANNETTE ST. L. SOMERS
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
in the back room of a tavern when she caught up with me.   Have you also read "Ishmael" 
and "The Hidden Hand" and "Tempest and Sunshine?" I read some of the darndest stuff,
at the same time that I was thrilling to poetry, which I dearly loved. The first poem I remember is
Wm. Allingham's "The Fairies," then Wordsworth's "The Cock is Crowing" and I thought
Tennyson's "Bugle Song" was the ultimate in beauty. (I still love its musical quality.)
I came down with rheumatic fever and later with "St. Vitus Dance" and I was told to stay out-doors
as much as possible with no more reading or playing the piano. I finally got around that by going
to my grandmother's and reading everything she had which included the "Arabian Nights," "Life
of Pope Pius the Ninth," "Jane Eyre" and "Samanthy at Saratoga" and old copies of The

Ladies Home Journal. When I was about 9 I read "Camille" and "Quo Vadis" because I saw my
mother hiding them back of some books, which only goes to show that if a youngster wants to
read there isn't much anyone can do about it.  I think that these self constituted censors of books
and movies have the wrong slant on the whole thing. Most kids won't see anything wrong until
they are told about it, after which they'll re-read it to find out where the high spots are supposed
to be.   although I hated high-school, I loved the Normal College. In my day it wasn't the "methods"
factory that it is now. We had an unusual group of teachers, most of whom went to Columbia and
Stanford later on. My favorite teacher was Elvira Cabell, first cousin of James Branch, and I never
can forget her. I had a course in Lyric Poetry with her, especially memorable because it has influenced
me all my life,

letterhead
JEANNETTE ST. L. SOMERS
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
and because I know now that she introduced us to the very best. I'll never forget her reading
of Ben Jonson's "Ode For Hesperus" and Shelley's "West Wind." later on, in another class
in American Lit. she read us Lanier's "Stirrup-Cup" and "The Marshes of Glynn," and I guess
that just about that time my taste in poetry jelled, because I have never been particularly
enthusiastic about anything I have read since. I keep going back to Shakespeare and the
Elizabethans and Shelley and Keats and I love Matthew Arnold's "Dover Beach." (I lived
in Berkeley, California for many years and at night when I looked out over the Bay and the
lights of San Francisco, it always came to my mind.)  Once in the Berkeley Library I found
an anthology of Irish poetry that I later tried to buy and found was out of print. Someday
I hope to pick it up in a second-

hand store, but I haven't found it yet.  My taste in literature is entirely my own. I don't like Browning or Whitman in
spite of all the reams of criticism, any more than I like Hardy's "Return of the Native" - another college must. I think
Edna St. V. Millay's "Murder of Lidice" is too much like a romantic adolescent trying to imitate "The Wreck of the Hesperus,"
and I can't read Thomas Mann to save my life. On the other hand, I love Francis Hackett's "Anne Boleyn," even though I
know it has too much conventional Merrie England and who'll buy-my-lavender atmosphere. His style gets me every time.
I read "Kristin Lavransdatter"once a year but I loathe Undset's modern stuff, and every summer I get the same thrill our of
"Huckleberry Finn."  My own books are what an artist might call the "genre" type. I like things that are different: an unusual
setting, unusual people, periods of history etc. Most of them

Jeannette St. L. Somers
11209 Vernon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois

are still in storage in California, but I have a few that I've bought since I came back, like 

"The Wooing of Jezebel Pettifer" and Moore's Sister Theresa". Remember how he hated that and
"Evelyn Innes"?) Incidentally, I  like Moore a lot.

Sometime if I ever read - crossed out get my daughter "raised" and self-supporting and get enough

ahead to take a year off, I'd like to take some work in harmony and composition to try my hand at working out
some of the junk that runs through my head. I'm of a musical temperament more than anything else although I
no longer sing, but from present indications I'll probably be crippled with arthritis or something before I can
manage to get some leisure. Teaching is a dog's life and I'm not letting my daughter get into it. All the arguments
about short hours and long vacations don't mean a thing, for the strain on one's nerves is so

intense, especially these days, that one simply couldn't endure any more of it. I look at some of the lady-welders and riveters cashing
in their huge pay-checks and think there's something ironic about the high valuation put on brawn.

I'm sorry that it has taken me so long to write but even this scrawl has taken two installments. I cane down with another

heavy cold that left me miserable but had to go to school as there are no substitutes to be had (They've either joined the Wacs or
gone into defense plants.)

Will you please remember me to Jack and give him ^my best wishes and thank you again for your reply to my note.
Cordially,   Jeannette Somers

Nov 21, 1985
Jack;

Scenes & Sayings; Images and Expressions keep coming to mind as I

remember THE DISINHERITED what a gripping work!! I surely am glad
that Peggy introduced me to you & your work!!

I hope you're writing again and seeing more clearly than ever before -

(meaning, of course, your eyesight)  Best wishes -

 Nancy Kress Sorgenfrei

printed in red SEASON'S GREETINGS

Dec. 21 '46
409 W. 22 St.
NYC || 
red floral border
Dear Jack and Gladys,

Many thanks for the beautiful card and Jack's letter, earlier. When I got

back I went to bed pronto with the flu and am only now getting up -
and there went my Xmas shopping! Gosh, I was so damned sorry to miss
seeing  Gladys - but this flu must have been coming on, and what with my
relatives pulling me different ways, I wasn't my own master of time. But I
will be back fairly soon, to teach puppetry at the Lincoln School among other
things - will have to keep more regular check on my folks. And next time, now
that I have your address, I'll

plan the visit in advance - with both of you.

Being in bed I couldn't do much about checking up on underline Slappy /underline

but I did phone the Jefferson library and it's on the shelves there and in their bookstore. The librarian
I wanted to talk to, Clara Ostrowsky, was home having herself a baby but I ran across her recommendations
in underline New Masses and underline Slappy was included there as well as in the Sunday Worker
(no review, just a line about its content each time), but since their recommendations are closely followed 
here as elsewhere, it should  help Xmas sales. I sure hope so. Bunny took the underline Masses & Workers /underline
aboard ship with him, so can't clip them yet. I'll stay on the trail, though, and once I'm up, will be able to get more done.

Best of everything to you both, (and what grown-up family)     Hortense

4916 N. Magnolia  Chicago 60640
Jan. 8, 1974
Dear Jack,

Thank you for the greeting you and Gladys send, and especially for your note...Bunni tried to get "Writers in Revolt"

at Volume One bookstore in Old town - never heard of it (tell your published). So yesterday I went to Kroch's downtown
for it. Oh Jack - it's marvelous! And, for me, it comes at just the right time. My own book "Two Artists" is devoted half to
Roff Bemen and art colony days of the thirties; even the second part, about Bunni's struggles as a sculptor demonstrates today's
need for revolt. Part I is finished, thirteen episodes, but Part II is a lot harder. Bunni is a much more complex artist that Roff
(whose paintings were representative window scenes and landscapes, much like Manet's). And of course Bunni is very much
alive and at first wanted mt to desist, objected to a biographical account (the book is semi-fiction) and "Write a novel about me
instead." But when he realized it was this or nothing, he did want his sculpture described and gave me the green light.

The clipping I've enclosed is one example of the commercial path taken by so many artists today. Jim used to be an excellent

painter and an idealist, studying Buddhist  philosophy, But finally, unable to withstand pressures from his social-climbing wife, he
gave up all painting for this crappy Krimpart.

Your introduction amazed me! I'd no idea who it really was that Nelson brought to Chicago. The history you give is fascinating and

your own part in it a glorious one. I'm glad you included that quote from Willard Motley - "unselfishly and without envy -" Both Bunni
and I have been badly hurt by

others' jealousy. You've been a rare friend to writers, and know your autobiography will get the acclaim you deserve. 
When I can make it to the Loop again (I still tire quickly, and bus fares are always a problem; even my paper, pens, stamps etc. 
come from friends) I'll try to find at the library the issue of "New Letters" that has the first section.

Tell Gladys - she may be amused - that my job as bus girl at Hillman's Cafeteria is a significant point in my story.
Could I ask a favor of you? I'd like very much to write to Meridel le Sueur. I long to be in touch with a woman writer. 

"Two Artists" is a women's love story. would you please take the time to send me her address, even if it's only a postcard?

Now after I take this letter to the Post office, I'll go to my library branch and start a publicity campaign for "Winters in Revolt."

All the librarians know me well, and most are book buyers.

Do, when you can, keep me informed of your writings. Bunni saves all reviews, interviews etc. to mail me, but not everything is in

Chicago papers. and I'm hoping to get Meridel's address from you soon.

Warmly - and gratefully,     Hortense
P.S. Have you publisher send copies of the announcement, a few to me and some to Bunni Sovetski, 2150 N. Halsted, Chicago ILL 60614.

He circulates a lot among non-conformists, and I'm trying to.

4916 N. Magnolia
Chicago ILL 60640
2-4-74
Dear Jack,

I'd have answered your so-welcome letter sooner but again have been battling flu, two months now! Resistance is low, working too

much non-stop on my book. But I did get letters off to Mendel and Amanda (it was thoughtful of you to include her address) and just
received a most beautiful answer from Meridel. Yes, what a remarkable woman she is! Also, the leaflet about the bookstore party.
Her words on it, as well as the drawing of her, moved me deeply. She too is doing a book on her struggles as a woman. She expects to
see you and the Rowlands this month.

One of the flyers you gave me was responsible for my branch library ordering a bound copy of the anthology, and know that two other

branches have also. Soon as I'm navigating again I'll continue to spread the word. By the way your own story in it is excellent. It reminded 
me of the better scripts of the Repertory Group.

Henry Black, whom I met at Commonwealth College, a librarian and a political writer, has stood by me thru the years and just send me another

$5.00. But, regretfully, I won't use any of it for the North Country anvil, it must be reserved for stamps.

I know Margaret Burroughs well (met Gwen Brooks at one of her parties) and went several times to the Museum location, then an art center.

I've heard much about the Museum but, for the time being, will hoard my energy for writing, too weary to get to Bunni's studio - he has
an exhibit in March in the art room of the downtown library and I do want, if possible, to see his pieces before they get carted to the Loop.
He was very pleased

to hear from you but is being short-sighted about his friend's interest in revolt. He'll probably change his mind, he changes daily.

It's good of you to speak of my help to you and Gladys. You, of course, had a good friend in Nelson, but Gladys at the time did

need a woman. I recall how sincerely she sang hymns, which surprised me. Now that I've listened twice, to Stud's broadcast of
the tape with you I understand this. I think you are both religious, in the best way. Like Dr. King.

Good Morning Revolution is a wonderful title. Bunni, who clips items to send me, will probably spot your review in Panorama 

and I'll be sure that it gets to Joni and others for ordering for branches.

My very best to Gladys and many many thanks to you.     Affectionately,     Hortense

Re. the other enclosures: "The Masses" I found in "Rising Up Angry" - a little "People's Newspaper sold in Chicago. 
he Kelley poem was in my file and I too am disturbed by the world food crisis, so decided I should share this with others. 
The poem in the mural I wrote to Min in August, & he liked it so much he asked if he could put it on the flyer for dedication. 
So - at the ceremony I was introduced along with the big shots (!) and later kissed by both Jim & the sweet girl artist - splendid people!
It was gratifying to see the community reading my verse - at last I am "heard" (the closing chapter of my book is titled "J? or I Shall
Be Heard!!"). The "Unweeded Portrait" also was part of the ceremony. At the lawyer's urging, when I mentioned I was so upset by the
news about our mutual friend Harry Appel that I had to write a poem, I brought it along to the funeral service, he showed it to the rabbi
& the entire service was based on my "portrait". Again I was mentioned by name as the "poet", from a pulpit this time. So - a second
time "heard".... No word from Bunni since he received Parts II and III over 2 months ago. Afraid he's badly hurt by my revelations -
it is a women's Lib ms. If he finally refuses to be identified as the second artist, I must go ahead without the readers knowing who he is.
I'm confident some day this

will be published, and have left it to Henry's son to follow them if in the future a publisher gets interested
(assuming there is a future for this world).

- Love -    Hortense

Saturday late aft, post office closed, so will guess at the postage  - want this at last in the mail to you!

poem, with handwriting written across it

 Ms Man

N  is like end

Nowhere beginning

To reach under the skin

A lacks completeness.

In all its beginnings

That surface the waves.

M  lacks in partial

What it does to fullness;

A tree with deep roots

Has a hook on this bee.

S  call the difference

It's equal

Beyond what the sameness

Would otherwise, be.

M  isn't partial

In climbing

To spell all its rythming [sic]

For all man to see.

written across the poem:
Hortense  As the Wheel of the mind unclear so time
Happiness is having unclear  Hope you enjoy this thought it has given me much to reflect

Love  Roberts

3-8-75
4916 N. Magnolia
Chicago ILL 60640
Dear Jack,

And what a dear you are! - offering to give your valuable time to my ms. But as it happens, fresh out of the hospital (

know now that medication & beer or whatever will not do so am learning to sleep via the hot milk routine, & when
wide awake after 2 hrs. or so, wash clothes etc. till I can sleep again). - anyhow I wobbled across the street to the
library, my mailing address for anything too large for my locked mailbox (you know what city kids are like these days)
and there was the return envelope from Sam B. Barker of the graduate school of University of Alabama. After seeing
his wife's use of a piece of Bunni's sculpture he bought last spring while in town for some educator's convention -
he's an art collector, & had no sculpture of wood, & someone told him about Bunni's exhibit at the library that month -
he bought "Beggar", a beautiful cowled bent head on a figure with maimed feet, and one of B's smaller things, a pregnant
woman - B. turns them out by the dozen for quick sales, carved from table legs. Anyhow he took B. to dinner, saw his
studio and both had a marvelous time - he's English & highly cultured. So at Union Pier just after Christmas I saw the card

2) his wife painted, very Japanese - like, with the Beggar amid flowers & trees - his art collection is mostly out of doors.
I got his address from B. & sent him the chapter "Sketch of a Sculptor," written while still married to B., descriptions of
each of the pieces he'd done to date - written originally, the first ones, when he was asked for biographical material for his
first exhibit at a furniture show at the Merchandise Mart, then continued because descriptions helped me to better understand the
carvings. But I've always worried about the "Sketch" - can verbal descriptions bring to life such a non-verbal art? So I mailed this
chapter to Dean Barker, with enclosed envelope stamped, to be simply mailed back if he had neither the time nor the inclination
to read it, and comment. My goodness Jack! Both of them, he & wife, not only read it several times but carefully wrote, revised,
wrote some more & finally sent me the wife's written comment with apologies for the delay. Wow! It begins "It is almost as though
we had seen the exhibit from your terse but affectionately sensitive descriptions..." Wife goes to say that she knows something about
B's work from the two they - crossed out he bought, & his descriptions of other pieces he saw in B's studio - "But your picturesque
writing makes pictures for me." The chapter ends with B's divorcing me - I'd omitted from the book much of the unpleasant -

3
ness that preceded the divorce, such as B's return from parties in which he was lionized, drunk, stinking of rum, & trying sadistically
to force sex on me. I merely said that his affectations - in mid-forties adopting teen-ager's slang, changing a title like The Flute Player"
to the flippant "Nature Boy" - because he played in the nude & that I couldn't tolerate it. Mrs. Barker quite correctly scolded me for not
being sympathetic to "his new get-with-it-ness". (Somewhere I'll have to explain my bias against any & all affectations, no doubt the
result of my mother who never should have been a mother in the first place, hypocritically cooing over the crying of new-born babies,
& talking baby-talk to our dogs & canines. Anyhow, she goes on to say that divorce is a familiar theme "more so all the time among our 
acquaintances and many don't wait for middle age. But it is an unusual setting and told in a poignant lyrical manner." Then both are puzzled
over the intent of what appears to be a "Slice of Life" story "such as the old New Yorker or Esquire used." And then, "Why not try writing his
story, his hurts?" Of

4) course I did, it's all in the book. So I'm sending on the ms. to this couple. If no more comes from it then a better understanding of the artist
they admire so much, that's quite enough. If I've an appreciative audience in this couple, it more than satisfied my wish, expressed in the title of 
the last chapter: "For I shall Be Heard!"

It might amuse you to read this bit of Harper-like verse I wrote in the hospital. Do you know anything about Basho and Issa? Basho was a century

before, and wrote poetic Haiku, but Issa followed the tradition of writing about everday [sic] happenings, including vulgar ones. In one of these he
describes the dismay of a family carting a horse with them on their tiny boat, when the horse "farted" & the wind blew the fumes into their faces. I
thought of this while in the hospital sharing a room with a Japanese woman who'd become a Roman Catholic while in one of those damned concentration
camps our inglorious country herded the Japanese into during the war. So she bore 11 children, & was working herself towards a stroke doing things for
the last three at home, in their teens but behaving like infants. I joined forces with Sache's? husband in insisting she change her habits on getting home,
while at the same time promising myself I'd make changes, the damned

5)
"water pills" to control high blood pressure wash all salts & minerals from my body, so I must control hypertension
thru rest etc. instead of medication.

Here's the verse:
 One room, two beds
 One woman peeing away
 One woman farting away
  -but changes are in the wind!

Thanks much for sending the clipping, which I'm returning, and for the address of the Beyond Baroque Foundation.
At my age any grant would be nonsense, but I'd be interested in getting the literary news.

And you will be hearing from that charming brat Roberto. I phoned his sister in Florida th - crossed out yesterday

morning, asking her to collect from various members of the family his best (earliest) poems to be sent to me. The
excellent job he has a chance to get in July, as activity therapist for retarded young adults, requires "ability to relate to
others" - he'd be working with their parents as well, and in his poems he reveals this clearly. And I asked for the letter
you wrote to him. Before I put a word in writing (my name is his chief reference) he

6) will learn some manners! He says he did greatly appreciate getting your books and read all the poetry and a bit else but "I didn't
answer the letter." By golly, he will!... do you believe in telepathy? I had a friend put a notice under the door that he uses as a mailing
address - he sleeps where he can, & since he's volunteering at this agency that will be funded in July, part of his work is in the kitchen
& he's getting fed. His coat is warm & presentable but he walks everywhere, & his gloves had no fingers. Fortunately I buy men's wear
when I can - much cheaper than women's - so had a pair of leather gloves that he managed to get his large bony fingers into... He's made
gigantic strides forward, and though he's into painting now rather than poetry - the drawings & water colors are quite good - he's still
basically a poet. Perhaps he'll turn into a sort of modern Walt Whitman. How he savors life! If he can only mature enough between now & July,
he'd be quite good in this job. He has much love to give, & he gives unstintingly.

Sorry I'm not strong enough yet to sit at the typewriter. Hope you can read the scribbling.
Many many thanks, Jack dear.   Love to you & Gladys
      Hortense.

4916 N. Magnolia
Chgo ILL 60640
6-20-75

Dear Jack - just a quick thank-you for that Baroque publication. A collect call to a good friend in Calif, ex-court reporter,

marvelous typist, got his okay to send d-crossed out along (I'm so tired! 1:50 A M) the 7 pages so far on the Nancy case -
not just propaganda, an artistic job interviewing the lives of 3, plus Nancy (my former pupil, about to be sent heaven knows
where - bright but pretending - fighting authorities the only way she knew how, a court case since age 3 & now headed for some
institution for retarded - she's over 21). I hope my book will do for her & others like her - what Sinclair did with "The Jungle.") So
there goes my summer!! I have deadlines, but will do my damndest to get this book into the Sept. 30 contest. since I save paper by
typing without margins, can't even guess at word-numbers etc. but Glenn will know, So sent him in a rush, before P.O. closed yesterday, 
all the pertinent material on Nancy. Her exploiting foster mother, who's had her since age 9, I know is making plans to cash in on whatever 
place she's "planning" for Nancy - I'm a "nobody", she's discovered, & her first pretence [sic] that Nancy's summer would be spent gardening
with her foster father - who does love her, evaporated - "She's helping me around the house. No, you can't see her, we won't be home, I take
her with me wherever I go" -  the girl's a prisoner!

A Walt Whitman poem's given me the links I need between the 3 separate lines - my landlord who died last October, and a most interesting

other pupil at the school where I taught Nancy. He is retarded, brain - damaged, but with a capacity for joy that lifts the gloom from my book.
Fortunately, besides the 4 poems I wrote about Nancy, I found 3 about Richard - and I'm hoping my book will fit into the "experimental" category.

Roberto has disappeared again - but sent Bunni a

poem & drawing. He's still hoping B. will invite him to Union Pier.

At the old town Art Fair B. almost sold out? Interesting how shrewd the buyers were - most of them old friends & collectors of B's work. the two pieces

left -out of ? weren't worth buying.

    What different characters we have, B. & I ! Just as it ruined our marriage, it continues to irritate me - he's so damned feudal in his subservience to people

with money or other assets. I could never put up with the set-up at Union Pier. At the moment he, his health, his own private garden behind the studio, are
wonderful. But if something should happen to Alexis - who goes - & gives - wild pot parties - his mother's brother would lay hands on that property at once -
and  history would be repeated for the third - he'd be out - everything he's built would become another's possession. There's not a scrap of paper giving him a
legal right to any of it - which cost not only labor but his own Social Security money - Alexis is mostly broke -  too sleepy!  Finish tomorrow.
...7-7-75. Many things kept me from finishing this - broken furniture needing replacements, confusion about new transfer to Social Security (still not all
clear) and mostly, recently, B's sudden & serious illnesses. eyes the worst, but bad health in many ways - and just wrote urging him to come to Chi. for a more
thorough diagnosis than available out there. yet leaving his beloved garden ("his" own, behind the studio, very private) would break his heart. I can't go up
there right now to talk to him, some serious dental work lined up, including an abcessed [sic] tooth. so I can't concentrate on the Nancy book yet... As soon as Glenn
(in Calif.) returns the Baroque publication, I'll pass it around - to Bunni, to an artist who needs a dealer etc...

-2-

Will back off to wash the floor, where the crippled "monster" of a chest had stood after Bob Smeltzer (a third baby drawers

needed) called for it yesterday - he can do the repairs at his studio - I swept up 3 inches of dust that's been piling up there behind it.
The Goldblatt's pieces that come tomorrow are light enough to more a round, & can replace what I've lost. (The lump sum from social
Security helped me buy them - at a sale.)

I'm in close touch with Margot Bemen Andreas now, who's changed completely from the hostile & jealous person she'd been, about Roff & me.

I think I told you both father & son Bemens are famous in Chicago, & If I could publish the small book on Nancy & the others, the one on the two
artists has a good chance. Margot would let me have photographs of his paintings that I've written about in my ms. ... Seeing Roff's "Self Portrait"
& others that Margot searched out & bought, at her apt. about 2 months ago was a shock. I was thrown back to my life with him. What wonderful
days those were! - despite all the torments. If only I'd been older, at that time, how differently I could have handled our problems!

Do, when you can, send me news of yourself... Henry Black from N.Y. sent clippings about Nelson. Poor lonely old man!.. How alike, in their 

weaknesses in relationships, he & Studs. The old Jewish problem?  Love to you two,  H.

8-22-75
Dear Jack -

 It was very good of you to send along the Newsletters issue (I agree on that nutty title!) - so tired I can hardly write, so this will be brief.

No, I'm quite sure the contest I read about isn't referred to here. It was specific about 3 categories, for unpublished writers, the 3rd was
"experimental prose & poetry" and the deadline Sept 30. Anyhow, have written them (air-mail) enclosing $1 to return it by same. Will
wait & see...In any case, am working hard on the book. I think it's good. It shall get circulated - I've a friend (a really slight acquaintance 
but has xeroxed free for me, & may be willing to continue,) And I can ask recipients to pay for costs - stamps etc. It's so important to air 
this terrible situation.    Can't keep my eyes open!... Will

send the Kansas City Star item along to Henry Black. He's grateful for any such - for his book "Road from Chaos" - on our
political mess and how to get out of it.   Thanks again!

Will keep you informed re. the contest - if blows up for me, at least you'll get my personal "publication" of: "One in My Building,

two in My File."   After this is finished, I am still on the battle-line - to help Nancy. Have already warned the Div. of Disabilities
(in charge of foster homes, for those over 21) that if I don't hear at once news of Nancy & how to see her, a letter goes to Action Line
of the Trib une. Very effective they are!  Love H.

H. Sovetski
4916 N. Magnolia
Chicago, ILL 60640

701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, MO
65270

Dear Jack - Wrote you months ago. Hope you & Gladys are well... Very encouraging letters from Meridel... Still trying to get back my copy
"Writers" its of your book - fine group of people waiting to read it... Would any small mags. that publish poetry in your area be worth the postage
to send a few? One of mine enthusiastically received by this group. Do let me know how you are. Love, Hortense

spring is coming is coming is coming!!!
4916 N. Magnolia
Chicago ILL 60640
2-22-75
Dear Jack,
Before I speak of Roberto, I'm anxious to know if you or anyone you know of, would have the time & inclination to read my book (the ms.) At first Margot Bemen,
Roff's younger daughter, was not only eager to read it but to add to it her own ideas about her father, lend a photograph of a landscape similar to the view from my bedroom window - a happy reminder of days with Roff, etc. Then - after I mailed her a copy, she won't even open it! Finally when I tired of her "reasons" (actually she's afraid what she'd read would wipe out some of the jealous hatred towards me she's had since I first entered Roff's life; her father - fixation, possessiveness is so deep that years with psychiatrists still haven't made a dent in it). Anyhow she's offered to buy the stamps herself & send it on to anyone I tell her about. Meridel wrote me she hopes to see me next summer & wants to read it but my experience with her last summer warns me she's not reliable these days - my money is scant, I may have to move from here - building bought by tenants who prefer my apt, etc. If I finally do see Meridel and I can be with her while she reads some of it, fine. Meanwhile, I'd like Margot to send it to someone before she changes her mind again. So I'm anxious to hear from you.
My health is awful now - very, very slow to get over a serious flu - has the epidemic hit your parts? I hope not! What worries me most is the worsening of a kidney - bladder condition I've had all

my life. I suspect it's a reaction to the "water" pills given me to lower blood pressure, Doctors!!
Roberto did get help from your books. He's in Chicago and staying away from Marty (which means from that cult too) and trying to get a job teaching. Bunni reports that when he first went to Alexis's looking for a place to sleep (Alexis is the photographer that owns the farm - orchard where Bunni was given a 2-story garage for a studio - he's made it charming! - I've been there twice & was supposed to go again but the flu had started) - Roberto looked like a seedy tramp. But I'm sure he's fixed himself up since, before the hunt for a teaching job.

Bunni also told me he saw Nelson & Studs in a farewell party on Channel 11 - I have no television set, refused it twice, eyes strained as it is - and that Nelson looks like a corpse! - so gaunt. I wasn't surprised as a picture of him in one of the papers showed something similar. I'm afraid this is the result of all his spitefulness. Hatreds eat into people.
When you can, do give me news of yourself + family, friends etc.
Larry Prugger offered to let me read part of your autobiography published in one of the university magazines which he sent for & since he doesn't have your anthology I was going to swap with him - but ill health prevented it.  Stay well!! And write soon as you can. Love to you both, Hortense

in red, at top: (died weekend of March 21, 1976)
12-26-75
Dear Jack & Gladys,

Apologies for such a late greeting - too much going on in a rush etc. Read an excellent review of Jack's -

some Irish book, I think - sent the clipping to Bunni.

The Ass. editor of Baroque returned my ms. with a nice note. He was moved by it but prefered [sic] it in other than

1st person singular, & more about "Noli" - my former pupil I'm hoping to help. But though I did make it longer,
little more about Noli was added. Soon as I can I'll type a decent copy to send to Craig, author of "P.S Your Not
Listening" -

think I told you, taught disturbed in Canada, good book. I do think most of my ms. is passable. Craig was in a pilot
program. God! How advanced Canada is, other countries too, compared to Watergate USA!!

"Look How the Fish Live" I enjoyed reading too... In touch with both Rowland & Meridel - wrote Meridel atop a dune

during a brief stay at Chris & Neal's. Chris xeroxed for me an article on Nelson, sad face, quotes from his writings etc.
Recently read "the non-story of the year: Algren's moving to Patterson." Meridel stayed with Amanda several days & did
much to get her out of her shell. Will try again to stir her by a letter when I can. How things pile up!

Hope 1976 brings you both good health. (Joy in living you already have)     Love  Hortense
